column3: We have a couple of things we work on

column3: We have dozens of products we work on

column4: In-product qualitative feedback (e.g. Send-a-Smile) and survey such as Net Promoter Score (NPS)

column2: Describe how your team collaborates, share risks, innovates, and learn?
column3: We keep to ourselves to avoid being blamed for failure.  Risk-taking is discouraged

column2: Describe how your team collaborates, share risks, innovates, and learn?
column3: There is some communication. When mistakes are made, there is justice for the responsible person

column2: Describe how your team collaborates, share risks, innovates, and learn?
column3: Communication and collaboration is good among teams. Innovation is encouraged.

column2: Describe how your team collaborates, share risks, innovates, and learn?

column4: There is high cooperation among teams. Risks are shared. Failure leads to learning and inquiry to help the team improve. Innovation is encouraged and implemented

column2: Describe how your team handles risk with a project?
column3: Prepare a clearly detailed scope of the project
column4: Prepare a clearly detailed scope of the project

column2: Describe how your team handles risk with a project?
column3: Define requirement specifications and acceptance criteria
column4: Define requirement specifications and acceptance criteria

column3: Get the stakeholders to sign off on this scope agreement
column4: Get the stakeholders to sign off on this scope agreement

column2: Describe how your team handles risk with a project?
column3: Determine what requirements need to be involved in the phase you are working on vs. future phases or versions
column4: Determine what requirements need to be involved in the phase you are working on vs. future phases or versions

column2: Describe how your team handles risk with a project?
column3: Develop and implement a change control process that the stakeholders are aware of and agree to

column2: Describe how your team handles risk with a project?
column3: Monitor the project progress against the scope

column2: Describe how your team handles risk with a project?
column3: None of the above

column2: Describe how your team regularly comes together to share and evaluate new ideas?
column3: We write them down, then follow up every couple of sprints to see what's there and decide what we will pursue

column2: Describe how your team regularly comes together to share and evaluate new ideas?
column3: We try to accommodate some time in the next sprint to look into some of the ideas that have come up

column2: Describe how your team regularly comes together to share and evaluate new ideas?
column3: We can discuss with the team and in case of good ideas can follow up immediately. This is why we have slack time in our schedule
column4: We can discuss with the team and in case of good ideas can follow up immediately. This is why we have slack time in our schedule

column4: Use a common code repository (for example: Git based repo) for source files

column4: Use a common code repository (for example: Git based repo) for configuration files

column3: Application source code and tests

column3: All files used to build, test, configure, deploy, run and document our service

column2: Describe how your team merges changes into a shared branch?
column3: Use Pull Requests to pull code changes back into the parent branch

column2: Describe how your team merges changes into a shared branch?
column3: Directly merge changes into the parent branch without a pull request

column2: Describe how your team merges changes into a shared branch?
column3: Directly change source code in the shared branch
column4: Directly change source code in the shared branch

column2: Describe the branch strategy in place to control pull/push requests?
column3: We keep new work in separate branches and merge it only when finished, usually within weeks or months

column2: Describe the branch strategy in place to control pull/push requests?
column3: We have no branches and develop only in the trunk or master
column4: We have no branches and develop only in the trunk or master

column2: Describe the branch strategy in place to control pull/push requests?
column3: We use branches that live for a few days at most and commit all changes to the master or trunk at least daily

column2: Describe the branch strategy in place to control pull/push requests?
column3: We maintain traceability on code changes but treat branches as temporary by using topic branches that we squash-merge to master when the work is complete

column2: Describe the branch strategy in place to control pull/push requests?
column3: None of the above

column2: Describe how the team monitors and reviews code changes?
column3: We do not have a policy; however, some code changes may undergo review, and at times, the reviewer may also be the requestor

column2: Describe how the team monitors and reviews code changes?
column3: We review code changes through live peer reviews or pair programming

column2: Describe how the team monitors and reviews code changes?
column3: Some code is reviewed, and we capture the review history using a pull request workflow or its equivalent
column4: Some code is reviewed, and we capture the review history using a pull request workflow or its equivalent

column2: Describe how the team monitors and reviews code changes?
column3: We ensure that all code changes are peer-reviewed before being committed to the master or trunk through a pull request workflow, branch policies, or their equivalent, and we enforce branch policies

column2: Describe how the team monitors and reviews code changes?
column3: None of the above

column2: Describe how your team deals with cross-team code dependencies?
column3: We track them in a spreadsheet or document

column3: We use a work item tracking system
column4: We use a work item tracking system

column2: Describe how your team deals with cross-team code dependencies?
column3: The dependencies are published as packages to a repository, so we can track the dependencies in our code. We publish our own artifacts as well so other teams that depend on us can see the new artifacts.
column4: The dependencies are published as packages to a repository, so we can track the dependencies in our code. We publish our own artifacts as well so other teams that depend on us can see the new artifacts.

column4: We have full access to the source code of other teams and can build our own version of the dependencies if necessary (inner source)

column4: We have a full open-source model, so anyone can contribute and use our code as well as we can use other team's code
